title: Unraveling virus-induced cellular signaling cascades by label-free quantitative phosphoproteomics
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Sample generation: virus infection and cell lysis
Timing: 6 days
Critical: The cells and virus should always be handled under sterile conditions in a biological safety cabinet. Prepare at least five independent replicates.
Remove medium from cells and wash them once with phosphate salt buffered solution (PBS) (Life technologies, #14190-094).
Add 1 mL of 0.25% trypsin-ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) (Life technologies, #25200-056) and incubate them at 37°C 5% CO2 until cells are detached.
Add 9 mL of pre-warmed cultivation medium and mix well.
Count cells using a cell counter or Neubauer chamber (Merck, #BR717805-1EA):
Mix 10 μL of cell solution and 10 μL 0.4% (w/v) Trypan blue (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #15250-061) and inject into a Neubauer cell counting chamber or an equivalent slide used for a cell counter.
Seed 2 × 106 A549 human lung epithelial cells (ATCC, #CCL-185) into a p100 dish (TPP, #93100) in 12 mL cell cultivation medium per dish.
Incubate cells at 37°C 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Wash the cells with PBS and incubate them in 12 mL DMEM (Life technologies, #41966-029) without supplements 16 h prior to infection.
Critical: This step helps to synchronize the cells and get rid of an important part of the serum albumin that is the main contaminant in the final samples (Nakhjavani et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14]).
Prepare SDS lysis buffer freshly (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
Critical: Prepare SDS lysis buffer freshly for each replicate, always keep it on ice and use within 1 day.
Add 3 mL virus inoculum per plate (containing 25 PFU/cell) or up to 3 mL of allantoic liquid from mock-infected eggs as a control in a tube and pre-warm inoculum to 37°C.

Critical: Always work in a biological safety cabinet when handling viruses. Do not add cold inoculum since this can trigger cellular stress pathways.
Suck off serum-free medium from the cells and add the inoculum directly to the cells and leave them at 37°C for 10 min.
Note: Infection time can be varied dependent on your experimental design.
After the desired infection time, directly lyse the cells in 400 μL of SDS-lysis buffer per p100 dish (TPP, #93100) and use a cell scraper (TPP, #99003) to remove lysed cells from the plate. Transfer lysate in a fresh 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube (Eppendorf, #0030121023).
Put Eppendorf-tubes on ice.
Incubate samples at 95°C for 5 min while shaking at 300 rpm in the ThermoMixer (Eppendorf, #538400001) and directly put them on ice again.
Briefly sonicate the lysates to reduce viscosity using a dry-sonicator (5 times 15 s pulse with 75% intensity) (Branson Ultrasonics Sonifier® SFX250, FisherScientific, #15569624) and put samples on ice again.Problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]
Centrifuge at 14,000 × g and 4°C for 5 min to clarify the lysate and transfer lysates into a fresh 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Pause point: Store the cell extracts at −80°C until you finished all replicates.
Filter aided sample preparation (FASP) and protein digestion
Timing: 1.5 days
Critical: Before you start, create a randomized list of your samples where each sample gets a number by chance and treat them randomized.
Quantify protein concentration using Qubit Flex Fluorometer (ThermoFisher Scientific, #Q33327) according to manufacturer’s protocol: (https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/Q33211#/Q33211[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/Q33211%23/Q33211]).
Add the Qubit buffer volume needed in an Eppendorf tube: 199 μL Qubit buffer per sample and 190 μL for each standard (3 in total).
Then add the Qubit reagent 1:200 (v/v) to the buffer and vortex mixture.

Aliquot 199 μL for samples and 190 μL for standards in Qubit tubes and add 1 μL sample or 10 μL of standard solutions to 500 μL thin-walled PCR tubes.
Vortex mixtures and incubate at 15°C–25°C for 15 min.
Measure according to Qubit instructions starting with the standard solution to calibrate the instrument.
Note: Alternatively, the Invitrogen EZQ Protein Quantitation Kit (#R33200) or any other fluorescent dye based protein quantification method can be used. Biuret methods cannot be used because the lysis buffer contains DTT.
Use 300 μg protein for each sample to start.
Prepare all solutions needed:
UA: 8 M urea in 100 mM Tris/HCl pH 8.2
IAA solution: 100 μL 0.05 M iodoacetamide in 900 μL UA
0.5 M NaCl in ddH2O
TEAB: 0.05 M Triethylammoniumbicarbonat in ddH2O
Critical: UA and IAA solutions must be freshly prepared and used within a day.
Label all tubes, lids and filters with the number from the randomized list of the corresponding sample.
Mix up to 50 μL of sample (containing 300 μg of protein) with 200 μL UA buffer and load onto the filter unit.
Critical: Samples should be at 15°C–25°C before you start centrifuging.
Centrifuge at 14,000 × g for 20 min at 15°C–25°C.
Discard flow-trough. Problems 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]
Repeat step 20 until everything is loaded on the filter (in case several steps are needed to load the total amount of protein).
Discard flow-trough.
Add 200 μL of UA to the filter unit.
Centrifuge at 14,000 × g for 20 min at 15°C–25°C.
Discard flow-trough.
Add 100 μL IAA solution (0.05 M) to the filter unit.
Mix at 600 rpm in the ThermoMixer for 1 min (lid open).
Centrifuge at 14,000 × g for 20 min at 15°C–25°C.
Discard flow-trough.
Add 100 μL of UA to the filter unit.

Centrifuge at 14,000 × g for 20 min at 15°C–25°C.
Discard flow-trough.
Repeat step 25 twice.
Add 100 μL of 0.5 M NaCl to the filter unit.
Centrifuge at 14,000 × g for 20 min at 15°C–25°C.
Discard flow-trough.
Repeat step 27 once.
Add 100 μL of TEAB to the filter unit.
Centrifuge at 14,000 × g for 20 min at 15°C–25°C.
Discard flow-trough.
Repeat step 29 twice.
Transfer the filter units to new collection tubes.
Reconstitute 20 μg lyophilized trypsin in 500 μL TEAB.
Critical: Make sure that the trypsin is completely dissolved. After adding TEAB, pipette 10 times up and down and incubate the solution for 10 min at 15°C–25°C.
Add 120 μL of TEAB with 2% trypsin (5 μg trypsin per sample) to the filter unit.
Mix at 600 rpm in the thermo-mixer for 1 min.
Seal all tube-lids with parafilm.
Incubate the units for 16 h at 15°C–25°C in a wet-cell.
Elution and peptide drying
Timing: 4 h
Centrifuge the filter units at 14,000 × g for 20 min at 15°C–25°C.
Critical: The flow-through of this step contains the digested proteins.
Re-elute the column by adding 80 μL of TEAB.
Centrifuge the filter units at 14,000 × g for 20 min at 15°C–25°C.
Transfer 10 μL of each sample into a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube for total extract samples and freeze them at -20°C.
Pause point: Samples can be stored at −20°C before drying.
Completely dry the rest of the digested peptides in a SpeedVac condensator at 35°C. This can take 2–3 h.

Critical: Partial drying of peptides at this and later steps increases the yield of phosphorylated peptides. However, complete drying may be more reproducible with regard to quantitative analyses. Time for drying can vary between samples and is dependent on factors such as the amount and type of peptides present. Problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]
Equilibration of MagReSyn® Ti-IMAC microspheres
Timing: 30 min
Prepare all solutions freshly before starting the enrichment:
70% EtOH in ddH2O
Loading buffer: 1M glycolic acid in 80% ACN, 5% TFA
Wash buffer 1: aqueous solution of 80% ACN and 1% TFA
Wash buffer 2: aqueous solution of 10% ACN and 0.2% TFA
Elution buffer: 1% NH4OH in ddH2O
Critical: The equilibration of microspheres should be performed immediately before sample loading. Wait until the samples are completely dry before starting the equilibration procedure. Equilibration of the total amount of microspheres (20 μL/ sample) can be done in one tube, indicated amounts of buffers are for one sample.
Resolve MagReSyn® Ti-IMAC thoroughly by vortex mixing or inversion to ensure a homogenous suspension.
Transfer 20 μL microspheres per sample to a 2 mL micro tube with a V bottom shape and screw cap.
Place the tube on a magnetic separator and allow microspheres to clear.
Remove the shipping solution (around 50% of the volume) by aspiration with a pipette and discard.
Wash the microspheres in 200 μL of 70% EtOH with gentle agitation at 900 rpm in the ThermoMixer for 5 min.
Place the tube on the magnetic separator and allow the microspheres to clear.
Remove the ethanol solution by aspiration with a pipette and discard.
Repeat the washing step 43.
Wash the microspheres in 100 μL of ddH2O (Millipore) with gentle agitation at 900 rpm in the ThermoMixer for 10 min.

Place the tube on the magnetic separator and allow the microspheres to clear.
Remove the buffer by aspiration with a pipette and discard.
Equilibrate the microspheres in 50 μL loading buffer for 1 min.
Place the tube on the magnetic separator and allow the microspheres to clear.
Remove the loading buffer by aspiration with a pipette.
Repeat step 46 twice for a total number of three equilibrations. After the last one, dissolve microspheres in a total volume equaling the sample number (20 μL for each sample).
Transfer 20 μL MagReSyn® Ti-IMAC to a 2 mL microcentrifuge for each enrichment.
Critical: Microspheres without the shipping solution are half the input volume. After removal of the loading buffer, MagReSyn® Ti-IMAC microspheres are ready for binding the target phosphopeptides.
Phosphopeptide enrichment using magnetic separator
Timing: 3 h
Prepare 10% FA solution in a chemical hood. To do so, calculate the amount you need and dilute formic acid 1:10 in ddH2O.
Resuspend dried digested peptides in 100 μL loading buffer.
Sonicate for 5 min in the water bath and shake 5 min in the ThermoMixer at 1000 rpm.
Centrifuge briefly at 14,000 × g and add to the equilibrated MagReSyn® Ti-IMAC microspheres.
Incubate for 20 min at 15°C–25°C with continuous mixing at 900 rpm in the ThermoMixer to ensure adequate sample and microsphere interaction.
Place the tube on the magnetic separator and allow the microspheres to clear.
Remove and discard the coupling supernatant by aspiration with a pipette.
Remove unbound sample by washing with 100 μL loading buffer for 1 min with gentle agitation at 900 rpm in the ThermoMixer.
Place the tube on a magnetic separator and allow microspheres to clear.
Remove the supernatant and discard.

Remove non-specifically bound peptides by adding the microspheres to 100 μL wash buffer 1 for 2 min with gentle agitation at 900 rpm in the ThermoMixer.
Place the tube on a magnetic separator and allow microspheres to clear.
Remove the supernatant and discard.
Repeat step 55 once.
Wash once with 100 μL wash buffer 2 for 2 min with gentle agitation at 900 rpm in the ThermoMixer.
Place the tube on a magnetic separator and allow microspheres to clear.
Remove the supernatant and discard.
Note: Washing with wash buffer 2 leads to better removal of hydrophilic peptides.
Elute the bound phosphopeptides from the microspheres by adding 80 μL elution buffer for 15 min at 900 rpm in the ThermoMixer.
Repeat step 58 twice for a final elution volume of 240 μL.
Place the tube on the magnetic separator and allow the microspheres to clear.
Remove the eluate containing the phosphopeptides and transfer to a new tube.
Add 60 μL of 10% FA to the 240 μL eluate to acidify the solution.
Critical: Prepare formic acid solution freshly in a chemical safety hood before using it. Phopshopeptides are not stable under basic conditions. Therefore, the solutions should be acidified immediately after elution.
Dry peptides from phosphoenriched and total samples using SpeedVac condensator at 35°C (1–2 h).
Reconstitute enriched peptides in 150 μL 3% ACN; 0.1% TFA.
Sonicate peptides for 5 min in the water bath and shake them 5 min in the ThermoMixer at 1000 rpm.
Centrifuge briefly at 140,000 × g.
Pause point: If you cannot directly continue with the desalting step, freeze samples at −20°C before drying or after reconstitution in 150 μL 3% ACN; 0.1% TFA.
Phosphoenrichment using the KingFisher Flex system
Timing: 1 h

After equilibration, transfer 20 μL MagReSyn® Ti-IMAC to a well in a KingFisher Flex Microtiter deepwell 96 plate and add 480 μL 100% ACN per well.
Prepare all solutions according to step 40.
Reconstitute dried peptides in 200 μL loading buffer.
Sonicate in the water bath for 5 min.
Mix solution well at 1000 rpm in the ThermoMixer for 1 min.
Transfer each sample to a separate well of a KingFisher Flex Microtiter deepwell 96 plate.
Critical: If you do not use each well, make sure that you use the same wells in each plate.
Prepare all KingFisher Flex Microtiter deepwell 96 plate with the amount and solution per well indicated in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]. Insert plates according to number into the KingFisher Flex instrument.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1360_14.csv
Use the KingFisher Flex instrument with the following steps and timing (in total 42 min, Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A). After elution, release beads into plate 2 (10 s release time) and tips in plate 1.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1360-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Graphical procedure overview
(A) Graphical overview of the different steps of the protocol.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1360-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Graphical overview of the automated phosphopeptide enrichment procedure
(A) Graphical overview of the automated phosphopeptide enrichment.
Transfer eluted peptides from each well of plate 8 to a separate 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Add 50 μL of 10% FA to each sample.
Critical: Prepare formic acid solution freshly in a chemical safety hood before using it. Phopshopeptides are not stable under basic conditions. Therefore, the solutions should be acidified immediately after elution.
Dry peptides from phosphoenriched and total samples using SpeedVac condensator at 35°C (1–2 h).
Reconstitute enriched peptides in 150 μL 3% ACN; 0.1% TFA.
Sonicate peptides for 5 min in the water bath and shake them 5 min in the ThermoMixer at 1000 rpm.
Centrifuge briefly at 14,000 × g.

Pause point: If you cannot directly continue with the desalting step, freeze samples at −20°C before drying or after reconstitution in 150 μL 3% ACN; 0.1% TFA.
Stop and go extraction (Stage) tip clean up
Timing: 3–7 h
Put Stage tips into a 2 mL Eppendorf tube with adaptors to hold Stage tips in place. Label tubes and Stage tips with sample number. Prepare two sets of fresh 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes for phosphoenriched and total samples. Label the lids and the tubes.
Critical: When working with Stage tips, visually check after each centrifugation step that the total amount of liquid passed the tip. If not, repeat centrifugation step for Stage tips with remaining liquid. Make sure that no Stage tip dries out during the procedure.
Wet Stage tip with 150 μL 100% ACN.
Centrifuge at 2,000 × g for 1 min.
Discard flow-trough.
Equilibrate Stage tip with 150 μL 60% ACN; 0.1% TFA.
Centrifuge at 2,000 × g for 1 min.
Discard flow-trough.
Equilibrate Stage tip with 150 μL 3% ACN; 0.1% TFA.
Centrifuge at 2,000 × g for 1 min.
Discard flow-trough.
Repeat step 84 once.
Put filters in fresh 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes.
Load sample on Stage tip.
Critical: Sample must have same pH as buffer in the second equilibration step. Concentration of organic solvent should be below 5% and is critical for peptide binding to the C18 material.
Centrifuge at 2,000 × g for 1.5 min.
Critical: Do not shorten this centrifugation step. Collect flow-through and keep at 4°C in case peptides do not bind.
Put filters back in 2 mL Eppendorf tubes.
Wash with 150 μL 3% ACN; 0.1% TFA.
Centrifuge at 2,000 × g for 1 min.
Discard flow-trough.
Repeat step 90 twice for a total of three wash steps.

Put filters in fresh 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes.
Elute sample with 150 μL 60% ACN; 0.1% TFA.
Centrifuge at 2,000 × g for 1.5 min.
Critical: Do not shorten this centrifugation step.
Collect flow-through in a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Completely dry desalted peptides at 35°C using a SpeedVac condensator (2–6 h).
Pause point: If peptides do not dry completely on the same day freeze at −20°C and continue drying the next day.
Reconstitute phosphoenriched samples in 10 μL and total samples in 20 μL of 3% ACN; 0.1% FA.
Sonicate for 5 min in the water bath and shake 5 min in the ThermoMixer at 1000 rpm.
Centrifuge briefly at 14,000 × g.
Pause point: Freeze at −20°C or directly proceed. Problems 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9], 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.11], and 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.13]
Analysis of peptides using mass spectrometry
If mass spectrometry measurements are outsourced to a specialized facility, skip this paragraph and directly continue with LFQ-based quantification of phosphorylation changes.
Critical: Mass spectrometers are highly sensitive instruments and should be maintained and used according to the manufacturer guidelines. This varies from instrument to instrument. Before you start using a mass spectrometer, always seek guidance of an expert and make sure the instrument is well maintained and properly calibrated.
Transfer 6 μL of sample in a mass spectrometry tube.
Critical: Increase fill volume if sample stays longer than 12 h in the mass spectrometer’s autosampler before being measured to ensure enough sample volume with regard to evaporation.
Spike samples with iRTs (BIOGNOSYS) with a dilution of 1:60 (v/v) directly before the measurement:
Vortex iRT buffer for 1 min
Add 50 μL of buffer to the iRT peptides
Sonicate in water bath for 1 min
Vortex and add to samples

Select the following parameters to measure on a Thermo Scientific™ Orbitrap Fusion™ Tribrid™ mass spectrometer coupled to an Easy-nLC 1000 HPLC system (Thermo Scientific):
Load 5 μL of peptides on the column from a cooled (4°C) autosampler.
Buffer A: 0.1% FA in H2O
Buffer B: 0.1% FA in ACN
For the measurement of phospho-enriched samples, apply the LC gradient described in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] and select the following parameters:
table:files/protocols_protocol_1360_15.csv
Acquire MS spectra in the Orbitrap mass analyzer with a mass range of 350–1800 (m/z), a resolution of 120,000 and a maximum injection time of 50 ms.
Acquire higher energy collisional dissociation (HCD) spectra in the ion trap mass analyzer using a normalized collision energy of 32% with a precursor ion isolation width of 2.0 (m/z) and a maximum injection time of 150 ms.
Set AGC target value = 2e4.
Enable charge state screening.
Include charge states 2–7.
Set the signal intensities threshold = 5e3.
Exclude precursor masses already selected for MS/MS acquisition for further selection during 30 s.
For total protein samples, apply the LC gradient in Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3] and select the following parameters:
table:files/protocols_protocol_1360_16.csv
Acquire MS spectra in the Orbitrap mass analyzer with a mass range of 300–2000 (m/z), with a resolution of 120,000, and a maximum injection time of 50 ms.
Acquire HCD spectra in the ion trap using a normalized collision energy of 30% with an isolation window of 1.6 (m/z) and a maximum injection time of 80 ms.
Set AGC target value = 8e3.
Set the intensity threshold = 5e3.
Set dynamic exclusion duration = 25 s. Problem 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.15]
LFQ-based quantification of phosphorylation changes
Timing: 12 h

The data analysis can be performed with every software that supports label free based quantification of post-translational protein modifications such as Progenesis QI (Waters, https://www.waters.com/waters/de_CH/ProgenesisQI/nav.htm?locale=de_CH&cid=134790652[href=https://www.waters.com/waters/de_CH/ProgenesisQI/nav.htm?locale=de_CH&cid=134790652]). Here, we describe in detail the analysis workflow using the open source software MaxQuant. MaxQuant adds known contaminants to the fast file and generates decoy hits for the false discovery rate (FDR) estimation. Your data base is therefore not allowed to have any decoy entries. MaxQuant is coupled to the search engine Andromeda provided together with MaxQuant.
Install MaxQuant on your computer.
Open MaxQuant folder and open Andromeda executable file (.exe).
Make sure that the database containing all annotated proteins of the organism you used is available by default in Andromeda. Problem 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.17]
Load either folder containing raw files of phosphoenriched or total samples into the software.
Critical: Analyze phoshoenriched and total samples separately.
Set experiment choosing “no fractions”.
Note: Only choose fractionation if your samples were obtained from a gel-based pre-fractionation.
Group specific parameters: Choose cysteine carbamidomethylation as fixed modification.
Note: Fixed modifications occur on every specified amino acid and are often artificially introduced by sample preparation. Cysteine carbamidomethylation is introduced to prevent disulfide bridges.
As variable modification, select protein N-terminal acetylation, methionine oxidation, N-terminal glutamate to pyroglutamate conversion and phosphorylation.
Note: Variable modifications increase the in silico peptide database. Only choose the ones necessary to keep computational time as short as possible.
Choose modification “phopsho STY” for phosphoenriched but not for total samples.
Choose label-free quantification.
Select digestion enzyme Trypsin/P.
Allow up to two missed cleavages.
Select First search.
Set fragment mass tolerance to 20 ppm.
Set precursor ion mass tolerance to 8 ppm.
Use sequences as global parameter: Minimum one unique peptide and a minimum of seven amino acids per identified peptide.

Note: If a peptide contains less than 7 or more than 9 amino acids it cannot be unique and is therefore not informative. Choose a value between 7 and 9.
MS/MS and sequence: Choose your created database.
Identifier: Up to first space - click identifier - identifierParseRule ([ˆ]∗).
Critical: Parse rules are applied to the FASTA sequence header. This parse rule applies for FASTA sequences form Uniprot. Adjust your parse rule accordingly.
Identification and quantification: For identification use a protein FDR of 0.05.
Miscellaneous: Choose Re-Quantify.
Note: Re-quantify allows peaks with no labeled pair to be re-searched based on their location or retention time.
Go to advanced and choose “Match between runs”.
Note: Allows information on identification from one run to be used in another run searching for peptide peaks closely located in the same retention time range.
Start analysis and check if steps are running fine in the performance menu.
The result will be saved as text files in the same folder as your raw files in a folder called “combined”. proteinGroups.txt for total samples and Phospho(STY)sites.txt for phosphoenriched samples. To see first quality control data, open the PTXQC report. Problem 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.19]
Exported lists of differently phosphorylated factors (p value ≤ 0.05 and log2FC ≥ 1 or ≤ −1) and total identified factors as background list can be submitted to further analysis tools (Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_1360_17.csv
